Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Small: Quantification and Visualization of Ensemble Uncertainty

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Uncertainty is inherent in scientific data. Quantification and interpretation of the uncertainty are essential to a holistic understanding of the data. Uncertainty representation is often overlooked in high-dimensional and multivariate data due to a lack of effective methods and a lack of guidance on appropriate existing methods. This project systematically investigates uncertainty visualization in high-dimensional data, within the application domain of meteorology. The interdisciplinary research team spans different areas such as visualization, atmospheric science, and statistics. The research team is investigating (1) quantifying uncertainty by using bootstrap mean confidence intervals, which relax assumptions about the underlying distribution; (2) designing a number of uncertainty visualization methods and implement these methods in an integrated user interface; and (3) employing both qualitative and quantitative user studies to evaluate the uncertainty visualization methods.

The resulting tools and methods are deployed to the Environmental Modeling Center. Although the primary application area of this project is meteorology, the principles learned have the potential to be applied to a variety of scientific fields, including hydrology, geospatial science, medical imaging, and biology. The research work of this project is integrated into Visualization and Meteorology classes at Mississippi State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Uncertainty is inherent in scientific data. Quantification and interpretation of the uncertainty are essential to a holistic understanding of the data. Uncertainty representation is often overlooked in high-dimensional and multivariate data due to a lack of effective methods and a lack of guidance on appropriate existing methods. This project systematically investigates uncertainty visualization in high-dimensional data, within the application domain of meteorology.

We looked at the spread in large-scale variables related to instability within extratropical cyclones that follow three primary storm tracks, Alberta Clippers, Colorado Cyclones, and East Coast cyclones.  The results showed that East Coast cyclones maintained greater instability due to the availability of the ocean, which enhanced those storms’ intensity in winter weather scenarios.  A second study investigated the ability to use artificial intelligence to discriminate tornado outbreaks from outbreaks which produce few tornadoes.  This was diagnosed using different configurations of a weather model to determine how the forecasts were sensitive to different model configurations.  The results showed certain configurations which were better for outbreak discrimination, which will have an impact in severe weather forecasting with major outbreaks.

We have designed, implemented, and evaluated ensemble uncertainty analysis and visualization methods. We used classical visual mappings like the color map, the transparency, the size and the shape of the visual marks. We employed contour tree layout to facilitate the visualization and interaction of the ensemble uncertainty. We incorporated ensemble uncertainty in the process of dimension reduction, hence producing a set of 2D or 3D points whose locational proximity reflects not only the value but also the ensemble uncertainty of the data.

We evaluated the effectiveness of the uncertainty visualization methods. We found that some widely used uncertainty visualization methods like error bar are not effective in visualization uncertainty while color and size are effective visual channels for uncertainty information. However, the effectiveness of different methods depends on the tasks and the users. We found that reducing the dimensions of the ensemble uncertainty data helps users better understand the data with uncertainty. However, the visualization will be more effective if the dimensions are reduced while preserving the uncertainty information.

We have applied ensemble uncertainty visualization to several domains. In numerical weather prediction, we used uncertainty to assess outbreak predictability, errors within the weather models, and winter storm characteristics.   In physiological simulation, we have visualized simulated ensemble patients as a set of 3D curves and identified important divergence within the group caused by inherent differences in physiology. In hydrology simulation, we have conducted uncertainty analysis on models and evaluated several methods for uncertainty analysis. In medical imaging, we have applied uncertainty visualization to diffusion tensor imaging which helped reveal the probabilistic nature of the tracked diffusion fibers.
